title:
Low-cost mobile 3D scanning of heritage objects to facilitate
  long-distance research collaboration
authors: Dirk HR Spennemann and Sharnie Hurford
abstract:
While three-dimensional visualization has become a common tool in various
cultural heritage applications, the emphasis has been on high fidelity
representation, essentially the generation of digital twins or digital
reconstructions. Overlooked appears to be the utility of 3D in research
collaboration where one of the researchers has access to the original,
potentially fragile object while the others are based in remote locations. This
paper describes the application of a low-cost, mobile and swiftly executable 3D
scanning process and discusses the benefits of this for remote collaboration of
three-dimensional objects of material culture
